ProceduralInterface module¶

class ProceduralInterface.DispItem(value, priority)[source]¶
class ProceduralInterface.PlasmaContext(obj, *args)[source]¶

Constructor for an interface object. Only one should be needed per application. The returned object has all the required methods for communicating with the GUI.

Parameters:
  • obj – Container object, this can be anything. It minimally must have two attributes dt and tend, both floats. dt is a time step and tend is end time of the simulation. For example, dt could be 0.1 and tend might be 100.0
  • args* – Parameters passed to main(args*). See Tutorials 1 for an example of useage.
RunNow(state)[source]¶
addGraph(codename, desc, autoadd=True, priority=100)[source]¶

Add a graph to the menu system. This is required to display a plot

Parameters:
  • codename – This is the computer’s name for a plot. It does not have to be human readable, but it never hurts to use a name that makes sense.
  • desc – The human readable name for the plot. This is what will appear in the right-click menu.
  • autoadd – Controls whether the plot is automatically displayed on startup. If set, a new plotting area will be automatically created.
  • priority – Automatically change order plots are displayed
clearGraphList()[source]¶

Clears the default items in the right-click menu. This is eventually going to be depracated

exit()[source]¶
fastForward()[source]¶

Allows the simulation to fast forward. Call immediatly after getEvents()

getEvents(pause=True)[source]¶

This is an important function, and must be called once per loop of the simulation. This function responds to input from the GUI. If this function is not called, the GUI will be unresponsive.

graphBeforeEndOfFF(plottype, interval)[source]¶

Tells te system to graph any plot objects of type plottype at time interval # of steps before the fastforward ends. This ensures that even if you fastforward past all of a plots graphing times, it will still draw the last one.

Parameters:
  • plottype – the string name of the plot
  • interval – how frequently the plot is generated. In time steps
isGraphing(name)[source]¶
newDynamicVariable(varname)[source]¶

Create a dynamic variable, that can be changed in the simulation loop. This variable will appear as red in the built-in input editor. When these variables are updated they will appear automatically as attributes in the container object specified in the constructor of PlasmaContext. The automatically created field will be all lowercase.

Parameters:varname – A string specifying the name of the dynamic variable as it appears in the editor.
newFrame(layout, defaults)[source]¶

Creates a new frame with a specified layout.

Parameters:
  • layout – The type of layout specified by a string, currently there are four options: “Layout1”, “Layout2v”,”Layout2h”, “Layout3”, and “Layout4”. These correspond to one plot, two plots arranged vertically, two plots arranged horizontally, three plots and four plots.
  • defaults – a list of plot names to display. If layout=”Layout3” then defaults must have length 3. The plot names correspond to the codename field in addGraph(codename, desc).
pause()[source]¶

Pauses the simulation

static runMain(func)[source]¶

This function launches the main simulation function in a child process. This is necessary, becase on OS X for whatever reason the GUI fails to respond if launched in the child process.

Parameters:func – The name of a function, which should take a single parameter. From the host process you would call PlasmaContext.runMain(main). main would be defined with prototype main(args*). main(args*) will call something like: pc = PlasmaContext(in1,*args) to create an interface object.
runOnce()[source]¶
setTime(time, dt)[source]¶

Sets the time in the control panel.

Parameters:
  • time – Simulation time
  • dt – Time step size

updateSimInfo(data)[source]¶

Updated simulation metadata. Currently the only field is ‘tend’, the end time of the simulation. This is done by passing a dictionary with key ‘tend’ as a string, followed by a float. For example, {‘tend’, 100.0}

wait(obj)[source]¶

Call after simulation loop has run. This command blocks and keeps the GUI responsive
